data.title: Hurricane at Apia, Samoa, 15
data.meta_description: This page features, or provides links to, all the views we have related to the Apia, Samoa, hurricane of 15-16 March 1889.
data.text:
Note: In addition to the views referenced above, the National Maritime Museum in Greenwich, England, holds several artworks that depict scenes before and during the Apia hurricane of 15-16 March 1889. Among these are:

National Maritime Museum photo # 7746 -- Oil painting by a German artist depicting the warships at anchor in Apia harbor shortly before the storm.

National Maritime Museum photo # 7747 -- Oil painting by a German artist depicting the warships in distress amid towering waves at the height of the storm.

National Maritime Museum photo # 58/6603 -- Engraving from a contemporary publication, depicting the ships at the height of the storm, with some of them being driven onto the reefs. This view has a heavy vertical line in its center.

National Maritime Museum photo # 2959 -- Etching by W.L. Wyllie, depicting HMS Calliope steaming out of Apia Harbor into the teeth of the hurricane. The view shows Calliope from off her stern (somewhat to the port side), with another ship (probably USS Trenton) beyond.

National Maritime Museum photo # 58/6590 -- Engraving from the "Illustrated London News", depicting the crew of USS Trenton cheering HMS Calliope as she steamed seaward at the peak of the hurricane. The artist's vantage point is from on board Trenton, with Calliope passing nearby (seen from off her port quarter).

National Maritime Museum photo # A.8339 -- Painting showing HMS Calliope escaping from Apia Harbor during the storm. The view shows Calliope from off her starboard side, with a huge wave breaking amidships.
